content.description:
This is the left most bolted climb on the lower face. The fourth bolt seems like it would only contribute rope drag, as the route is "done" after the second clip.

The crux is between the first and second clips, and invlves an awkward balancy move that is a dyno for short people. There are 4 huecos in and after the crux, and the friction on all of them sucks.
content.protection: 4 bolts to a 2 bolt top anchor. Walk off or bring long (10' +) slings for a top rope.

content.description:
Climb starts on a steep overhang with pretty good but spaced out holds. Crux is between the 2nd and 3rd bolt trying to get over onto the face above.

This route is often very mossy at the top but can be cleaned and climbed, probably best in the summer.
content.protection: 5 bolts to two bolt anchor. You can walk off the back or lower down. It is a good idea to clip the first bolt from the ground before starting the climb.
content.location: In between Cum Slot and High on Testosterone

content.description:
This route ascend the bolted left-middle section of the south side of Indian rock. Climbing is getting up a featured slab, a crux is located around the second bolt.

This is a good top rope route for children, as many of the holds can be complimented by "kid size" intermediate holds along the way.
content.protection:
2 bolts to a 2 bolt top anchor.

Climb up the left side of the rock to access the top bolts for a top rope.

Instead of standing on the ledge below the bolts try to access the top anchor from above.

content.description: Climb into the cave and then up on some edges. Brushing the moss away for good foot holds until the lip

Climb the middle-right set of bolts on the south face. The crux is an interesting bulge move right before the second bolt. Kind of a one move wonder route, as the climbing is the easiest on the face (5.5ish) after the second bolt.
content.protection: 2 bolts to a 2 bolt top anchor.

content.description:
Located in the middle of the south side, this route is nearly always in the shade.

This interesting climb isn't too much about power, just keeping yourself balanced on a route with minimal footholds. There's a 5.11 move in the bottom near the first bolt that involves a smear move, and then sustained 5.11 lieback from the second bolt to the top, getting tougher as you move up. The crux is getting yourself to the top anchors, as the feet are non-existant in this section.

For an added burn, link this up with hocus.
content.protection:
3 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor. On lead, you can protect the section after the first bolt with a large (2 1/2" - 4") friend (#3 BD Camelot, Marroon Metolius Supercam).

Bring short slings (3') for a top rope. The top of this route can be accessed without climbing it by down climbing from the top of Indian Rock from the south side, though be careful, this is non trivial. The best place to set a toprope is at the top of hocus, rappelling in from the top of south face.

content.description: Instead of starting Jail Bird on the left and traversing in, start on the large jugs on the left side of the cave formation at the base. Clip the old crappy spinner, use the sloper rail, and power your way to a crimp which marks the start of the normal Jail Bird crux. Adds a grade or so, but also makes Jailbird way more fun. Easily toproped by scrambling up the left side chimney.
content.protection: 2 questionable bolts to a 2 bolt anchor on a ledge. Best toproped, conceivable as a highball.
content.location: start on the big wacos on the left end of the cave at the base on the south face of Indian.

content.description:
This climb is located directly above Krokus.

The start is from the block with Krokus' top anchors, and a belayer should probably be clipped into these anchors to avoid falling to the bottom of the south side (50+ feet) in the event that the first bolt on the route blows.

This slab climb has an interesting beginning move to get from a large flake onto a slab that has literally no holds on it. Getting from the first to the second bolt is terrifying, and run out. A fall in this area will send you tumbling over the roof, which would not be fun.

The crux seemed to be from above the first bolt to 4 feet shy of the top anchor.

If you don't trust your feet, don't do this climb!
content.protection: 2 bolts to a 2 bolt top anchor.

content.description:
Basically 15 feet of relatively easy climbing (5.10ish) followed by a stout V4 (old-school graded) boulder problem. Not a great route, but could be entertaining if you are a stronger climber than I am.

Start up the left side of the arete, making cool moves with great jugs, clipping the first two bolts with ease. Then fire the wicked-hard boulder problem - a long move off of marginal feet to a terrible sloper, then crank for the good holds.
content.protection:
2 bolts to a 2 bolt-anchor. TR possible by scrambling in from the left chimney or by climbing "South Face" and traversing in from the right.

The first bolt is pretty sketchy - I wouldn't fall on it.
content.location: Furthest left climb on the Southwest Face of Indian Rock (the face you first come to as you approach from the parking lot). Right of the large easy chimney you can scramble up to set a TR.

content.description: This route begins in the overhanging offwidth crack on the side of Indian Rock that faces the Globule. After the offwidth start follow a discontinuous thin crack up to a small roof leading to the final summit slab.
content.protection: Couple of 5" pieces for the lower offwidth. Small to medium in the middle. Quick draws for final roof. Bring a couple of 3.5" pieces for anchors.

content.description:
Climb the arete on the right side of the South face, working mostly around the corner in the tall narrow pocket. The climb consists of a large juggy haul up an overhung section of the rock, with a fun reachy finish at the top.

For the 12a finish, work up and well left from the fourth bolt, and it's 11c if you continue up the arete.

Be mindful that even though you've climbed the first 10 feet of the climb, there is stall groundfall (or slabfall, I guess) after the first bolt.
content.protection:
5 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor. The anchor is not on the top of the climb, but over the bulge. If you want to toprope this climb bring either two single length slings or a double length quad or equalized sling for the anchor.

There are quick links on both anchor bolts, however the bolts are on either side of a fin which would be a nightmare to try to pass rope over, more worth it to either lower off of one of the bolts’ quicklinks or leave draws up there and clean them by scrambling along the summit arête to the top of the route.

content.description: This route goes up through a big alcove into a cave and exits the cave out onto a short slabby finish before the bolted anchor. Set up is by top rope, access anchors the front (uphill) side of Indian rock.
content.location: On the downhill side of indian rock. Climb goes up the big shallow alcove into cave. Climbers right of the gully.

content.description: Climb up the honeycomb on the right side of the cave (right of Donkey Dong) then past 3 bolts. The route was designed to be lead apparently. To TR you'll want to setup a TR anchor at the Hocus bolts and extend down quite a ways with some cord/webbing. Setting up on the bolts to the left runs the rope over an edge.
content.protection: Hangers have been removed, though the old bolts are still poking out of the rock. Top-rope only.
content.location: Starts on the right side of the cave next to Donkey Dong, above Vicious Circles/Blowing Bubbles.

climbs.name: Blowing Bubbles
climbs.fa: Brad Watson (Flash) 7/2/91 of Bruce Morris RT

content.description:
"Blowing Bubbles" is an interesting line that is harder than it looks but is likely easier than it's rated. A good warm-up for "Viscious Circles", which is considerably stiffer but similar in style.

Start up low angle features to the right of the bolt line, executing some committing moves to reach the first bolt. I thought this was the mental crux of the route, but it appeared that small gear would have protected this section. Climb more positive pockets to reach a distinct thin crux just past the second bolt. Find the big holds and finish off with increasingly easy (but runout, unless you bring slings for tie-offs or bigger cams) terrain to the anchors.
content.protection:
2 bolts to a 2-bolt anchor

-- Small cams or nuts may be useful if you're nervous about the high first bolt

-- A long sling might be use useful to tie off a hole in the rock above bolt 2

You can easily top-rope the route by walking around to the 2-bolt anchor
content.location: The second route from the left on the NE face (downhill side of Indian rock). Just right of Viscious Circles.

climbs.name: [Redacted]
climbs.fa: Brad Watson (TR) 11/24/91 of Bruce Morris RT

content.description:
An interesting name for an interesting route.

Start with an intriguing 5.10ish slab move that is well protected by a bolt (this is supposed to be the crux...). After a brief crack section (stoppers useful), you reach the base of the intimidating chimney. You can skip this first part by scrambling up to the base of the chimney from the right.

The chimney is reportedly 5.8 if you are good at these types of "ooze moves". It felt hard to me. Pro is tricky but it's all there.
content.protection:
Set of cams to 3 inches. Stoppers and small cams helpful.

2-bolt anchor
content.location: On the downhill side of Indian Rock, towards the right side. Find the obvious chimney and look hard for the lone bolt on a slabby face.
